lesson.name: Lesson 6.7: General Strategy for Factoring Polynomials

page.title: 6.7.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will review each strategy learned throughout this unit to assess the best strategy to factor polynomials. You will be presented with different polynomials, and, without additional context, you will find the fully factored form of each.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Recognize and use the appropriate method to factor a polynomial completely.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 6.7.1: Factoring Strategies for Polynomials
  • 6.7.2: Reviewing General Strategies to Factor a Polynomial
    • 6.7.2: Self Check
    • 6.7.2: Additional Resources
  • 6.7.3: Implementing General Strategies for Factoring
    • 6.7.3: Self Check
    • 6.7.3: Additional Resources
  • 6.7.4: Is the Polynomial Completely Factored?

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 6.7.5: Practice
  • 6.7.6: Lesson Summary

page.title: 6.7.1: Factoring Strategies for Polynomials
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity


  1. Working with a partner, list as many strategies as you can for factoring polynomials.

Enter your answers here:

Your answers may vary, but here are some examples:

  • Factoring by finding the GCF of an expression and using reverse distribution
  • Factoring using grouping
  • Factoring trinomials of the form \(x^2 + bx + c\) (undo FOIL)
  • Factoring trinomials of the form \(ax^2 + bx + c\) using trial and error
  • Factoring trinomials using the “\(ac\)” method
  • Factoring using substitution
  • Factoring the difference of squares
  • Factoring perfect square trinomials


  1. Work with your partner to write a sample polynomial that would be fitting for each strategy listed.

Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answers:

Factoring Strategy

Sample Polynomial

Factoring by finding the GCF of an expression and using reverse distribution

\(14a + 8ab + 12\)

Factoring using grouping

\(x^2 + 2x − 5x − 10\)

Factoring trinomials of the form \(x^2 + bx + c\) (undo FOIL)

\(t^2 + 14t + 24\)

Factoring trinomials of the form \(ax^2 + bx + c\) using trial and error

\(18x^2 − 3xy − 10y^2\)

Factoring trinomials using the “\(ac\)” method

\(16x^2 − 32x + 12\)

Factoring using substitution

\((x−2)^2 + 7(x−2) + 12\)

Factoring the difference of squares

\(81y^2 − 1\)

Factoring perfect square trinomials

\(25v^2 + 20v + 4\)

page.title: 6.7.2: Reviewing General Strategies to Factor a Polynomial
page.contents:
Activity

Take a moment to look at all parts of the diagram. Are there any parts that you do not understand?

Use this time to ask your teacher if there is something you would like clarified here.

Use the diagram above as needed for the activity.

Determine the best strategy to factor the polynomial. Explain your reasoning. Remember to factor out the GCF first, if necessary, before choosing a strategy. If a polynomial is prime, write “prime.” An example is provided.

Polynomial

Reasoning

Strategy

\(4x^2 + 20xy + 25y^2\)

After GCF, trinomial of form \(a^2 + 2ab + b^2\)

trinomial square pattern


  1. \(8y^3 + 16y^2 − 24y\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

After GCF, trinomial of form \(x^2+bx+c\); undo FOIL



  1. \(16x^3 − 36x\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

After GCF, a binomial of squares; difference of squares



  1. \(6pq^2 − 9pq − 6p\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

After GCF, trinomial of form \(ax^2+bx+c\); “\(ac\)” method or trial and error



  1. \(4x^2 − 12xy + 9y^2 − 25\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

polynomial of 4 terms; grouping



  1. \(a^2 + 9\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

no factors; prime



  1. \(9x^2 − 24xy + 16y^2\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

trinomial of form \(a^2  − 2ab + b^2\); trinomial square pattern



  1. \(27y^2 − 48\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

After GCF, a binomial of squares; difference of squares



Extending Your Thinking

Factor the polynomial below. Write down every factoring strategy that you use.

\(9x^2 − 12xy + 4y^2 − 49\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\((3x − 2y −7)(3x − 2y + 7)\); Strategies Used: 

Factor out GCF, grouping, perfect square trinomial, difference of squares

Here is how tto factor this polynomial:

Step 1
Is there a GCF?
\(9x^2−12xy+4y^2−49\)
No.

Step 2
With more than three terms, use grouping. The last two terms have no GCF. Try grouping the first three terms.

Step 3
Factor the trinomial with \(a \neq 1\). But the first term is a perfect square.
Is the last term of the trinomial a perfect square?
\((3x)^2−12xy+(2y)^2−49\)
Yes.

Step 4
Does the trinomial fit the pattern \(a^2 \pm 2ab + b^2\)?
( 3 x ) 2 ↘ −12 x y + −2 ( 3 x ) ( 2 y ) ↙ ( 2 y ) 2 − 49 ( 3 x ) 2 ↘ −12 x y + −2 ( 3 x ) ( 2 y ) ↙ ( 2 y ) 2 − 49
Yes.

Step 5
Write the trinomial as a square.
\((3x−2y)^2−49\)

Step 6
Is this binomial a sum or difference? Of squares or cubes? Write it as a difference of squares.
\((3x−2y)^2−7^2\)

Step 7
Write it as a product of conjugates.
\(((3x−2y)−7)((3x−2y)+7)\)
\((3x−2y −7)(3x−2y +7)\)

Step 8
Is the expression factored completely?
Yes.

Step 9
Check your answer by multiplying.
\((3x−2y−7)(3x−2y+7)\)
\(9x^2−6xy−21x−6xy+4y^2+14y+21x−14y−49\)
\(9x^2−12xy+4y^2−49✓\)

page.title: 6.7.2: Self Check
page.contents: Which strategy would you use to factor \(40x^2y + 44xy − 24y\)? What is the factored result?

answer.answer_text:
Factor out the GCF. Use the undo FOIL method.

\(4y(5x + 2)(2x − 3)\)
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The GCF is \(4y\). Since the first term of the remaining trinomial does not have a coefficient of \(1\), this is not the best strategy. Use the “\(ac\)” method. The answer is \(4y(5x − 2)(2x + 3)\).

answer.answer_text:
Factor out the GCF. Use the difference of squares.

\(4y(5x − 2)(5x + 2)\)
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The GCF is \(4y\). The remaining polynomial is a trinomial, and you cannot use the difference of squares. Use the “\(ac\)” method. The answer is \(4y(5x − 2)(2x + 3)\).

answer.answer_text:
Factor out the GCF. Use the “\(ac\)” method.

\(4y(5x − 2)(2x + 3)\)
answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: The GCF is \(4y\). The remaining trinomial has the form \(ax^2 - bx + c\). You can use trial and error or the “\(ac\)” method.

answer.answer_text:
Factor out the GCF. Use the perfect square trinomial strategy. 

\(4y(5x + 2)(2x − 3)\)
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The GCF is \(4y\). The remaining trinomial does not have the form \(a^2 + 2ab + b^2\) for that method. Use the “\(ac\)” method. The answer is \(4y(5x − 2)(2x + 3)\).

page.title: 6.7.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Reviewing General Strategies to Factor a Polynomial

You have now become acquainted with all the methods of factoring that you will need in this course. The following chart summarizes all the factoring methods we have covered and outlines a strategy you should use when factoring polynomials.

These are the steps to use when deciding how to factor a polynomial. We will review an example after looking at these steps.


Use a general strategy for factoring polynomials:

Step 1
Is there a greatest common factor? Factor it out.

Step 2
Is the polynomial a binomial, a trinomial, or are there more than three terms?

If it is a binomial:

  • Is it a sum?
    • Of squares? Sums of squares do not factor.
    • Of cubes? Use the sum of cubes pattern.
  • Is it a difference?
    • Of squares? Factor as the product of conjugates.

If it is a trinomial:

  • Is it of the form \(x^2+bx+c\)? Undo FOIL.
  • Is it of the form \(ax^2+bx+c\)?
    • If \(a\) and \(c\) are squares, check if it fits the trinomial square pattern.
    • Use trial and error or the “\(ac\)” method.

If it has more than three terms:

  • Use the grouping method.

Step 3
Check.

  • Is it factored completely?
  • Do the factors multiply back to the original polynomial?

EXAMPLE 1

Factor completely: \(24y^2 − 150\).

Be careful when you are asked to factor a binomial because there are several options!

Step 1
Is there a GCF?
\(24y^2 − 150\)
Yes, \(6\).

Step 2
Factor out the GCF.
\(6(4y^2 − 25)\)

Step 3
In the parentheses, is it a binomial, a trinomial, or are there more than three terms?
Binomial.

Step 4
Is it a sum?
No.

Step 5
Is it a difference? Of squares or cubes?
Yes, squares.
\(6((2y)^2 − (5)^2)\)

Step 6
Write as a product of conjugates.
\( 6(2y − 5)(2y + 5)\)

Step 7
Is the expression factored completely? 
Neither binomial can be factored.

Step 8
Check your answer by multiplying.
\(6(2y − 5)(2y + 5)\)
\(6(4y^2 − 25)\)
\(24y^2 − 150✓\)

EXAMPLE 2

Use the diagram and questions as references. Which strategy would you use to factor the following polynomials in the left column of the table? Explain your reasoning.

Look at each polynomial. Review the steps to decide which strategy to use.

Polynomial

Strategy

Reasoning

\(x^2 − 3x − 10\)

\(4a^2 − 12ab + 9b^2\)

\(4y^2 − 25\)

Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answers:

Polynomial

Strategy

Reasoning

\(x^2 − 3x − 10\)

undo FOIL

trinomial of form \(x^2+bx+c\)

\(4a^2 − 12ab + 9b^2\)

trinomial square pattern

trinomial of form \(a^2 − 2ab + b^2\)

\(4y^2 − 25\)

difference of squares

a binomial of squares


Try It: Reviewing General Strategies to Factor a Polynomial

Identify the strategy you would use to factor each polynomial.


  1. \(4x^2y − 16xy + 12y\)
  1. \(4x^2 + 8bx − 4ax − 8ab\)

Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Often, there will be more than one strategy that can be used to factor a polynomial. Here are some sample solutions.

  1. Factor out the GCF of \(4y\). Use the undo FOIL method on the remaining polynomial since it is of the form \(x^2+bx+c\).
  1. Factor out GCF of \(4\). Then factor by grouping since there are four terms.

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 6.7.3: Implementing General Strategies for Factoring
page.contents:
Activity

Work with a partner on these problems. After each solution, discuss if there are multiple strategies that would work to factor the polynomial.

Find a strategy that fits and factor completely: 


  1. \(5y^3 − 15y^2 − 270y\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Factor out GCF of \(5y\). Then use the “undo FOIL” method on the polynomial of the form \(x^2 + bx +c\).
\(5y(y − 9)(y + 6)\)



  1. \(75m^3 + 12m\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Factor out GCF of \(3m\).
\(3m(25m^2 + 4)\)



  1. \(16x^2 + 24xy − 4x − 6y\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Factor out GCF of \(2\). Then use the grouping method.
\(2(4x − 1)(2x + 3y)\)



  1. \(2n^2 + 13n − 7\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Use the “\(ac\)” method or trial and error.
\((2n − 1)(n + 7)\)



  1. \(121r^2 − s^2\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Use the difference of squares method.
\((11r − s)(11r + s)\)



  1. \(25w^2 − 60w + 36\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Use the perfect square trinomial method.
\((5w − 6)^2\)



  1. \((3x + 1)^2 − 6(3x + 1) + 9\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Use the substitution or perfect square trinomial method.
\((3x−2)^2\)



  1. \(16x^2 − 24xy + 9y^2 − 64\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Use the grouping method on the first three terms. They are a perfect square trinomial. Then use the difference of squares on the result.
\((4x − 3y − 8)(4x − 3y + 8)\)



Video: Determining Factoring Method

Watch the following video to learn more about how to determine which method of factoring will be best to apply.

page.title: 6.7.3: Self Check
page.contents: Which strategy would you use to factor \(9x^2 − 24xy + 16y^2\)? What is the factored result?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The polynomial has the form \(a^2 − 2ab + b^2\). This fits the trinomial square pattern strategy. The signs do not match up with this answer since the second term is negative. The correct answer is \((3x − 4y)^2\).

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The polynomial has the form \(a^2 − 2ab + b^2\). This fits the trinomial square pattern strategy. Grouping is good when there are more than three terms. The correct answer is \((3x − 4y)^2\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The polynomial has the form \(a^2 − 2ab + b^2\). This fits the trinomial square pattern strategy. The correct answer is \((3x − 4y)^2\).
That’s correct! Check yourself: The polynomial has the form \(a^2 − 2ab + b^2\). Square the factors to check that they are equal to the original polynomial.

page.title: 6.7.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Implementing General Strategies for Factoring

Let’s practice recognizing and implementing these strategies as we factor polynomials.

Remember, a polynomial is completely factored if, other than monomials, its factors are prime!

EXAMPLE 1

Find a strategy that fits and factor completely: \(7x^3 − 21x^2 − 70x\).

Step 1
Is there a GCF?
\(7x^3 − 21x^2 − 70x\)
Yes, \(7x\).

Step 2
Factor out the GCF.
\(7x(x^2 − 3x − 10)\)

Step 3
In the parentheses, is it a binomial, a trinomial, or are there more than three terms?
Trinomial with leading coefficient \(1\).

Step 4
“Undo” FOIL.
\(7x(x \;\;\;)(x \;\;\; )\)
\(7x(x + 2)(x − 5)\)

Step 5
Is the expression factored completely? 
Yes. Neither binomial can be factored.

Step 6
Check your answer by multiplying.
\(7x(x + 2)(x − 5)\)
\(7x(x^2 − 5x + 2x − 10)\)
\(7x(x^2 − 3x − 10)\)
\(7x^3 − 21x^2 − 70x✓\)

EXAMPLE 2

Find a strategy that fits and factor completely: \(4x^2 + 8bx − 4ax − 8ab\).

Step 1
Is there a GCF?
\(4x^2 + 8bx − 4ax − 8ab\)
Factor out the GCF, \(4\).
\(4(x^2 + 2bx − ax − 2ab)\)

Step 2
There are four terms. Use grouping.
\(4 \lbrack x(x + 2b) − a(x + 2b) \rbrack\)
\(4(x + 2b)(x − a)\)

Step 3
Is the expression factored completely?
Yes.

Step 4
Check your answer by multiplying.
\(4(x + 2b)(x − a)\)
\(4(x^2 − ax + 2bx − 2ab)\)
\(4x^2 + 8bx − 4ax − 8ab✓\)

EXAMPLE 3

Find a strategy that fits and factor completely: \(40x^2y + 44xy − 24y\).

Step 1
Is there a GCF?
\(40x^2y + 44xy − 24y\)
Factor out the GCF, \(4y\).
\(4y(10x^2 + 11x − 6)\)

Step 2
Factor the trinomial with \(a \neq 1\) using the “\(ac\)” method or trial and error.
\(4y(5x − 2)(2x + 3)\)

Step 3
Is the expression factored completely?
Yes.

Step 4
Check your answer by multiplying.
\(4y(5x − 2)(2x + 3)\)
\(4y(10x^2 + 11x − 6)\)
\(40x^2y + 44xy − 24y✓\)

Try It: Implementing General Strategies for Factoring


Find a strategy that fits and factor completely: 

  1. \(27y^2 − 48\)
  1. \(6x^2 − 12xc + 6bx − 12bc\).

Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to factor these polynomials:

  1. difference of squares; \(3(3y − 4)(3y + 4)\)
  1. grouping; \(6(x + b)(x − 2c)\)

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 6.7.4: Is the Polynomial Completely Factored?
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity


  1. Explain what it means to factor a polynomial completely.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

To factor a polynomial completely means that every factor you have found, or the polynomial itself, is prime.


Determine if each polynomial is completely factored. If the answer is no, write the completely factored form.


  1. \(3x(8x^2 − 9x − 3)\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

yes



  1. \(60x^2y − 75xy + 30y\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

no;
\(15y(4x^2 − 5x + 2)\)


  1. \(2c(4c^2 + 20cd + 81d^2)\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

yes



  1. \(5n^2 + 5n + 12\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

yes



  1. \(5q^2 − 15q − 90\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

no;
\(5(q + 3)(q − 6)\)



  1. \(64x^2 + 16xy + y^2\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

no;
\((8x + y)^2\)

page.title: 6.7.5: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

  1. \(36x^2y + 15xy − 6y\)

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 6.7.2 and 6.7.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(3y(3x + 2)(4x − 1)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(49b^2 - 36a^2\)

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 6.7.2 and 6.7.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \((7b − 6a)(7b + 6a)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(49b^2 − 112b + 64\)

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 6.7.2 and 6.7.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \((7b − 8)^2\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(7b^2 + 7b − 42\)

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 6.7.2 and 6.7.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(7(b + 3)(b − 2)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(15pq − 15p + 12q − 12\)

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 6.7.2 and 6.7.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(3(5p + 4)(q − 1)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(4x^2 + 40x + 84\)

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 6.7.2 and 6.7.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(4(x + 3)(x + 7)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(m^2 + 14mn + 49n^2\)

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 6.7.2 and 6.7.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \((m + 7n)^2\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \((4x − 5)^2 − 7(4x − 5) + 12\)

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 6.7.2 and 6.7.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \((4x − 9)(4x − 8)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(8m^2 − 32\)

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 6.7.2 and 6.7.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(8(m − 2)(m + 2)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(9x^2 − 6xy + y^2 − 49\)

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 6.7.2 and 6.7.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \((3x − y + 7)(3x − y − 7)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 6.7.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Recognize and use the appropriate method to factor a polynomial completely.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 6.7.1: Factoring Strategies for Polynomials
    • In this activity, you identified all the polynomial factoring strategies you have learned in this unit. You created sample polynomials that would fit into each strategy.
  • 6.7.2: Reviewing General Strategies to Factor a Polynomial
    • In this activity, you reviewed the strategies used to factor polynomials. When given a sample polynomial, you assessed it and determined an appropriate strategy for factoring.
    • 6.7.2: Self Check
    • 6.7.2: Additional Resources
  • 6.7.3: Implementing General Strategies for Factoring
    • In this activity, you used every strategy you have learned to factor different polynomials. You combined strategies to completely factor polynomials of many different forms.
    • 6.7.3: Self Check
    • 6.7.3: Additonal Resources
  • 6.7.4: Is the Polynomial Completely Factored?
    • In this activity, you analyzed different polynomials and assessed if they could be factored further or if each factor in the polynomial was prime.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 6.7.5: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
